div1.p: Barker provides general biographical information on Jesse Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Lewellys F. Barker to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, July 30, 1940
div1.opener:
New London,
New Hampshire
July 30, 1940
President R. C. Hutchison
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pa.
My dear President Hutchison:
div1.p:
Your letter, sent to me in Baltimore, has been
forwarded to me here where I am spending my summer vacation.

I am delighted to know that the memory of the late
Dr. Jesse Lazear, who was an alumnus of Washington and
Jefferson College, is to be honored by naming a chemistry
building after him. Unfortunately, owing to other appoint-
ments in October, I cannot be with you on October twenty-
sixth when the building is to be dedicated. Dr. Lazear
sacrificed his life that others might live.

During the time (1895 - 1900) when Doctor Lazear was
working at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, I was living in the
hospital and knew him well and greatly admired him because of
his high ideals and pleasing personality. He had taken his
A. B. degree at Johns Hopkins University in 1889 and his
M. D. degree at Columbia University (College of Physicians
and Surgeons) in 1892. He had then served as interne in
Bellevue Hospital, New York City, for two years, after which
he pursued post graduate studies in Europe (especially in Paris)
for one year. On his return to America in 1895, he became
Assistant Resident Physician (service of Professor Osler)
-2-
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital. In the summer of 1896, he
married and began private practice in Baltimore, but
acted also (until 1900) as assistant in the teaching of
Chemical Microscopy in the Johns Hopkins Hospital and as a
member of the Out-Patient Staff of the hospital.

In February, 1900, he left for work in the medical
service of the U. S. Army, going to Columbia Barracks, near
Havanna, Cuba. He was a member of the group (headed by Dr.
Walker Reed) that undertook the study of the cause of Yellow
Fever. He volunteered to be one of those who allowed them-
selves to be bitten by a certain mosquito that had bitten
yellow fever patients. Dr. Lazear developed the disease and
died of it at Quema doo, Cuba, on September 25th, 1900.

He had written a paper entitled “Pathology of
Malarial Fevers, Structures of the Parasites and Changes
in Tissue,” which was published (after his death) in the
Journal of The American Medical Association for Oct. 13th,
1900.

In the Johns Hopkins Hospital Bulletin (1900,
Vol.XI, p. 290) will be found an obituary notice written by
the late Dr. William S. Thayer.

In the same journal in the following year (1901,
Vol. XII), an appeal was made for subscriptions for a memorial,
the committee consisting of Dr. William Osler, Dr. Stewart
Paton, and Dr. William S. Thayer.

In the Bulletin in 1902 (Vol.XIII, p. 25), it was
stated that the fund raised as a memorial would be used as
a permanent scholarship for the study of tropical diseases
or as a library fund.

For other references to the life of Dr. Lazear,
please consult:
(1) J. Am. Med. Assn. 1900, XXXV, 895
(2) Science, 1900, M.S. XII, 932
(3) " 1901, M.S. XIV, 253
